Warli is an Indo-Aryan language spoken by the Warli tribal community, primarily in Dadra and Nagar Haveli. It reflects the rich cultural heritage of the Warli people, known for their distinctive art forms.
Dhodia is a language spoken by the Dhodia tribe in the region. It is part of the Bhil subgroup of Indo-Aryan languages and contributes to the area's tribal linguistic diversity.

Bhili, also known as Bildoli, is spoken by the Bhil tribal community in Dadra and Nagar Haveli. It is related to Gujarati and Rajasthani languages and is written using variations of the Devanagari script.
Konkani is spoken by some communities in the union territory, reflecting the cultural and linguistic diversity of the region.

Considered the basis of Standard Hindi and Urdu, Khari Boli is an Indo-Aryan dialect that originated in the regions around Delhi. It gained prominence during the Mughal era and became the foundation for modern Hindustani languages.

Emerging in Delhi during the Mughal period, Urdu developed as a lingua franca among soldiers and citizens, blending Persian, Turkish, Arabic, and local dialects. It became a significant cultural and literary language in Delhi.
An Indo-Aryan language spoken in the region around Mathura, Braj Bhasha was an important literary medium from the 15th to the 19th century. It has influenced the linguistic landscape of Delhi.
A dialect of Western Hindi, Haryanvi is spoken in the neighboring state of Haryana and has influenced the linguistic patterns in Delhi due to geographical proximity and migration.

With significant migration from Punjab, Punjabi has become widely spoken in Delhi. It is an Indo-Aryan language with a rich literary tradition and has contributed to the cultural diversity of the city.
During the Mughal era, Persian was the official language of administration and culture in Delhi. Its influence is evident in the city's architecture, literature, and the development of Urdu.
A form of Hindustani used in poetry, Rekhta blends Persian and local dialects. It gained prominence in Delhi's literary circles during the Mughal period.

Kashmiri is an Indo-Aryan language spoken by around 7 million people, primarily in the Kashmir Valley. It has a rich literary tradition and is one of the 22 scheduled languages of India. In 2020, it was declared an official language of Jammu and Kashmir.

Dogri is an Indo-Aryan language spoken in the Jammu region. It was recognized as a scheduled language in 2003 and became an official language of Jammu and Kashmir in 2020. Dogri has a rich oral tradition and is known for its folk songs and literature.

Ladakhi, also known as Bhoti, is a Tibetic language spoken in the Ladakh region. It shares similarities with Tibetan and uses the Tibetan script. Ladakhi reflects the unique cultural and religious heritage of the region.

Balti is a Tibetic language spoken in the Kargil district of Jammu and Kashmir. It has preserved many archaic features of the Old Tibetan language and is written in the Perso-Arabic script. Balti culture is known for its rich traditions in music and dance.
Shina is a Dardic language spoken in the Gurez and Dras valleys. It has several dialects and is known for its rich oral literature, including folk tales and songs.
Gojri is an Indo-Aryan language spoken by the Gujjar community in various parts of Jammu and Kashmir. It has a rich tradition of folk literature and is recognized for its unique cultural expressions.

Pahari-Pothwari is spoken in the Pir Panjal Range, particularly in the Poonch and Rajouri districts. It serves as a linguistic bridge between Punjabi and Hindko and reflects the cultural diversity of the region.
Bhadarwahi is an Indo-Aryan language spoken in the Bhaderwah region of Jammu and Kashmir. It has its own distinct linguistic features and contributes to the cultural diversity of the state.
Sarazi is spoken in the Doda district and serves as a transitional dialect between Kashmiri and Dogri. It reflects the linguistic diversity of the region.
Burushaski is a language isolate spoken by a small community in the northern regions of Jammu and Kashmir. It has no known linguistic relatives and is considered endangered.

Ladakhi, also known as Bhoti, is a Tibetic language spoken predominantly in the Leh district of Ladakh. It has several dialects, including Lehskat (spoken in Leh), Shamskat (northwest of Leh), Stotskat (in the Indus Valley), and Nubra (north of Leh). While it uses the Tibetan script, Ladakhi is not mutually intelligible with Standard Tibetan.

Zangskari is a dialect of Ladakhi spoken in the Zanskar region. It has four sub-dialects: Stod, Zhung, Sham, and Lungna. Zangskari reflects the unique cultural and linguistic heritage of the Zanskar valley.
The Changthang dialect is spoken by the Changpa nomads in the Changtang region of eastern Ladakh. This dialect reflects the nomadic lifestyle and high-altitude pastoral culture of the Changpa people.

Balti is a Tibetic language spoken in the Kargil district of Ladakh and in the Baltistan region of Pakistan. It has preserved many archaic features of Old Tibetan and is written in the Perso-Arabic script by Muslims and the Tibetan script by Buddhists.

Purgi is spoken in the Kargil district and is considered a transitional dialect between Ladakhi and Balti. It shares linguistic features with both languages and reflects the cultural amalgamation of the region.
Brokskat is spoken by the Brokpa community in the Dha-Hanu region of Ladakh. It is an Eastern Dardic language and is considered endangered, with a limited number of speakers maintaining its use.
Shina is a Dardic language spoken by the Dard-Shin community in the Dras and Gurez valleys. In Ladakh, it is primarily spoken in the Dras region of Kargil district.
The Brokpa community, residing in the Dha-Hanu region, speaks a dialect known as Brokskat. This language is part of the Eastern Dardic group and is unique to this small community in Ladakh.

Jeseri, also known as Dweep Bhasha, is a dialect of Malayalam spoken in the Lakshadweep archipelago, particularly on the islands of Chetlat, Bitra, Kiltan, Kadmat, Amini, Kavaratti, Androth, Agatti, and Kalpeni. It has similarities to Arabi Malayalam, reflecting historical interactions with Arabic-speaking traders.

Mahl is a dialect of Dhivehi spoken on Minicoy Island (Maliku) in Lakshadweep. It shares linguistic features with the Maldivian language and has been influenced by Arabic and Persian due to historical maritime connections.

Maliku is a dialect of Dhivehi spoken on Minicoy Island in Lakshadweep. It shares linguistic features with the Maldivian language and has been influenced by Arabic and Persian due to historical maritime connections.

Arabi Malayalam is a traditional dialect spoken by the Mappila community of the Malabar Coast, which has influenced the Jeseri dialect in Lakshadweep. It incorporates numerous Arabic loanwords, reflecting the Islamic cultural heritage of the region.
Serving as the primary official language, Tamil is predominantly spoken in the Puducherry and Karaikal districts. It reflects the Dravidian heritage of the region.
Telugu holds official status in the Yanam district, where it is widely spoken by the local population.
In the Mah district, Malayalam is the official language, reflecting the area's cultural alignment with the neighboring state of Kerala.
A remnant of colonial history, French continues to influence Puducherry's culture. While its use has declined, it remains an official language and is evident in signage and some local institutions.
Serving as a link language across the Union Territory, English is used for official purposes and is widely understood.
Pondicherry Tamil)
items.Reference Link: Local variations of Tamil in Puducherry exhibit unique linguistic features influenced by historical French contact, distinguishing them from standard Tamil.

items.Description: Tamil-French Creole)
items.Reference Link: Developed during the colonial period, this creole combines elements of French and Tamil, though it is now endangered with few remaining speakers.
